article.description:
Marc Jackson scored 21 points to lead Utah
to a 69-56 win over Wyoming on Monday, handing Rick Majerus his
400th coaching victory.
article.headline: Utah remains tied for first in MWC with victory
article.linkText: Majerus earns 400th win, as Utes edge Wyoming
article.story: LARAMIE, Wyo. (AP) -- Marc Jackson thought he detected something unusual about his coach, who had just earned his 400th career victory. ''We saw a little crack of a smile,'' the Utah guard said of his mentor, Rick Majerus. ''We usually don't see him smile, so that must mean he's pretty happy. We're pretty happy.'' Who could blame Majerus or the Utes? They notched their first victory at Wyoming in a decade, never trailing over the final 27 minutes and coasting to a 69-56 triumph late Monday night, their 13th victory in 14 games. Jackson sank six of 10 shots from the floor including three of four from 3-point land to lead Utah (18-4, 6-1 Mountain West) with 21 points. But he preferred to talk about Majerus instead of the victory, which kept the Utes tied for first in the league with Brigham Young. ''That's a great job by Coach. 400 wins. That's a great job,'' he said. Majerus was quick to credit his players, including the many unsung ones through the years. ''Players win games. Coaches don't win games,'' he said. ''It's a tribute to the players I coach. ... 'I just am real fortunate. I've enjoyed the guys I've coached and I've been lucky to have them.'' Tim Frost added 16 points and Nick Jacobson 15 for the Utes, who picked up their first victory in Laramie since Jan. 28, 1993, snapping a seven-game skid in the Arena-Auditorium. Donta Richardson led Wyoming (16-6, 4-3) with 23 points. Uche Nsonwu-Amadi had eight points and 13 rebounds for the Cowboys but wasn't much of a factor offensively, taking only five shots. ''(Cameron) Koford and (Chris) Jackson did a nice job against Uche,'' Majerus said. ''It was a team effort defending that big guy, and we were able to limit him.'' Jackson said the Utes showed good patience. ''We took good shots and that's the key,'' he said. ''We just tried to grind it and tried to pick.'' The Cowboys were left wondering how to recapture the magic of their back-to-back conference title campaigns. Wyoming is now two games behind BYU and Utah. Although they battled to a 33-33 standoff in rebounds, the Cowboys' Joe Ries was disappointed in the board effort. ''I still think we're not rebounding like we're capable of,'' he said. ''We've gotta bounce back. Pretty much that's all there is to it. ... It comes down to defense. Defense and rebounding.'' Richardson said the race isn't over yet. ''As I remember we dropped three games last year and still won the conference championship,'' he said. ''Some may say it's over. It ain't. We still have seven games left.'' Majerus is 400-138 in his 19th season as head coach, including stops at Marquette and Ball State. In 14 years at Utah, he is 301-86. Wyoming lost three consecutive conference games for the first time in four seasons. The Cowboys had not lost back-to-back conference home games since 1994-95. The Utes shot 46 percent, including 8-for-14 from the arc, while the Cowboys sank only 37.5 percent, their third-lowest of the season. Utah held Wyoming to one field goal during an eight-minute stretch of the second half to put the game away. After Jay Straight's 3-pointer for Wyoming tied the game at 35 with 16:02 remaining, Utah went on a 13-3 run. Trace Caton had a putback and 3-pointer and a layup by Marc Jackson capped the surge, which left the Utes up 48-38 with 8:18 to play. The lead reached 55-44 on Jacobson's running jumper at the 4:49 mark and then 67-53 on two free throws by Frost with 48 seconds remaining. Over the last nine minutes, Wyoming could draw no closer than seven points. Jackson scored 10 of his points in the first half to stake Utah to a 30-26 lead at intermission.
